source.sqlReaderQuery:
SELECT t1.*,t2.createddate FROM EmulationActivityDynamicDescriptionValue t1 LEFT JOIN EmulationActivityLogs t2 on t1.emulationactivitylogid=t2.id
WHERE CAST(t2.createddate AS DATE) < DATEADD(DAY,-10,CAST(GETDATE() AS DATE)) or t2.id is null

scripts.text:
DELETE t1
FROM EmulationActivityDynamicDescriptionValue t1
LEFT JOIN EmulationActivityLogs t2
    ON t1.EmulationActivityLogId = t2.Id
WHERE CAST(t2.CreatedDate AS DATE) < DATEADD(DAY, -10, CAST(GETDATE() AS DATE))
    OR t2.Id IS NULL;

DECLARE @BatchSize INT = 10000;  -- Define the batch size for deletion
DECLARE @RowsAffected INT = 1;    -- Initialize with a non-zero value
DECLARE @TotalRowsDeleted INT = 0; -- Variable to accumulate total rows deleted
DECLARE @LoopCount INT = 0;       -- Variable to count the number of loop executions
 
-- Start the batch-wise deletion process
WHILE @RowsAffected > 0
BEGIN
    -- Increment the loop execution count
    SET @LoopCount = @LoopCount + 1;
 
    -- Delete top (@BatchSize) rows based on the purge condition
    DELETE TOP (@BatchSize)
    FROM businessdata.EmulationActivityDynamicDescriptionValue
   WHERE CAST(createddate AS DATE) < DATEADD(DAY,-47,CAST(GETDATE() AS DATE))

    -- Get the number of rows deleted in the last batch
    SET @RowsAffected = @@ROWCOUNT;
 
    -- Accumulate the total number of rows deleted
    SET @TotalRowsDeleted = @TotalRowsDeleted + @RowsAffected;
END
 
-- Optionally, you can output the total rows deleted and loop execution count for logging purposes
SELECT @TotalRowsDeleted AS TotalRowsDeleted, @LoopCount AS LoopExecutionCount;
